text: Randy Wadkins: I'm as Mississippi as it gets.
I've eaten possum.

I grew up staying with my grandmother in her
trailer.

You know, I have the advantage that I'm from
there and I grew up there and so it's not

like I'm some outsider who just moved to Mississippi
decided to run for Congress.
That’s not what’s going on.
[Crowd noise]

One of the things that I'm trying to do with
this run is to get folks to think about what

are the 21st century jobs that we want to
bring to the state of Mississippi, especially
the 1st Congressional District.
Just next door in Alabama, in north Alabama,
they have Huntsville.
They have aerospace industry.

They have a brand new biotech industry that's
popping up.
Google just put a facility in Alabama.

And there's no reason that we can't also have
that, those sorts of jobs in north Mississippi.

We’ve just got to have somebody with some
vision to work on that problem.
That's why I'm running .

I would say most people in Congress don't
really understand how to connect the gears

together and to understand that tweaking something
over here produces a result on the other end.
And I think scientists do understand that.

I think that's sort of our breadbasket is
understanding and unmasking how things work.

Party politics is really complicating a whole
lot of things at the federal level that shouldn't
be there.

So I think if you get especially scientists
who are very pragmatic, who are there to solve

a problem, we don't have a particular political
agenda.

Honesty and actual facts are the coin of our
realm, things that we have to deal with.

Even if you don't like what we're saying,
you have to listen.

These are actual facts, not fake facts or
alternative facts.

I think the Trump administration is the most
anti-science administration in my lifetime.

The Trump budget for 2018 came out in, I guess
March of 2017.

And it proposed, among other things, 25% budget
cut for cancer research, massive cuts for
the National Science Foundation, the DOE.

Things that fund chemistry, things that fund
science at all levels of the United States.

And I decided that I wanted to do something
about that.

I think that having someone with a science
degree enter these realms forces an elevation
in the conversation.
That we we have to start talking about facts.
We have to talk about scientific reality.

We have to talk about how to make fact-based
policy because that's not what's happening
right now.

And so if scientists just sit on the sidelines
and do nothing, that's what we're going to
continue.

We're going to continue to have policy that's
being made that has no basis in reality.

So get involved even, if you don't run
for office yourself get involved with politics

because it's critically important for the
future of the country.
